profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:32

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: A collection of unrelated papers, linked by the family connections of the major figures. The papers of David Humphreys, a diplomat in the service of the United States, document his activities in Spain, 1789-1808. Also included are personal papers including correspondence with David Bushnell and Ezra Lee about submarines and with James Madison on politics, and some family correspondence. The papers of George William Erving, who was charg√© d'affaires in Madrid (1804-1809) during Humphreys' tenure, complement the Humphreys diplomatic papers. The Marvin and Lemuel Gregory Olmstead (also Olmsted) families are represented by correspondence concerning life in New York and Connecticut in the 19th century. Of particular interest is a series of some sixty letters from Sarah Lucy Olmstead to her father describing her life in Erie, Pennsylvania from 1860-1865. Also in this part of the collection is a family photograph album and a journal kept by Lemuel Gregory Olmstead of his travels in New York State during 1830.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Humphreys-Marvin-Olmstead Collection (MS 857). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Griswold family and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by name of family member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection is composed of fragmented groups of papers pertaining to the interrelated Humphreys, Marvin, and Olmsted families; they date from the Revolutionary War era through the first half of the nineteenth century. The papers fall into five distinct and unrelated series, each devoted to a different family or group of families. For the convenience of the researcher, a detailed genealogicalchart has been provided, which identifies all family members represented in the collection.

By far the most important person having a place in this collection is David Humphreys, Revolutionary War officer and United States diplomat, whose papers make up the first and largest series (see the description of Series I). Humphrey's papers, which are concerned for the most part with his diplomatic activities in Spain from 1789 to 1808, are complemented by diplomatic papers of George William Erving, charge d'affaires in Madrid from 1804 to 1809 (Series II). These two sets of papers together thus provide a useful resource for the student of early American diplomacy.

Series III and IV contain correspondence, legal and financial papers, genealogical materials, and memorabilia of the Marvin and Lemuel Gregory Olmsted families. While neither series is very large or coherent, a picture does emerge of everyday life in Connecticut, New York, and Pennsylvania during the early 1800s.

The fifth series is composed of four separate small collections of papers pertaining to Joel Barlow, the Cary and Dwight families, and John Trumbull, and of a collection of miscellaneous autographs (see page 61). Since John Trumbull materials are also located in Series I and II, an index to all the Trumbull materials has been compiled.
The Humphreys-Marvin-Olmsted Collection (Manuscript Group Number 189) by Wolcott Griswold Lane, a descendant of the Griswold and Colt families.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David Humphreys: soldier, statesman, poet; B.A., Yale, 1771, M.A., 1774; lieutenant colonel and aide-de-camp to Washington during the Revolution; appointed special secret agent in 1790 to gather information for Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson; appointed commissioner of Algerian states; in 1793 appointed minister plenipotentiary to Spain; in 1796, upon his return to the U.S., founded the Humphreysville Manufacturing Company.
For a chart outlining the genealogical relations of the Humphreys, Marvin, and Olmstead families, please consult theGenealogical Chart.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For an index of authors and the boxes in which their materials are located, please consult theAuthor Index.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, which is divided into seven sections, is devoted to papers of the diplomat David Humphreys (1752-1818). The bulk of the papers (1789-1808) deals with Humphreys' labors in Europe as an agent of the United States government, both as commissioner for Algerian affairs empowered to negotiate peace with Algiers and arrange ransom for American prisoners, and as minister plenipotentiary to Spain charged with maintaining peaceful relations with Spain and her American colonies.

The first section, Diplomatic Correspondence,is made up of five sub-sections. The first contains letters written to Humphreys by successive secretaries of state, supplemented by a letterbook in the fifth sub-section (Box 4, folder 111) of letters from Secretary of State Edmund Randolph. These letters provide detailed instructions for Humphreys' missions to Europe, discuss the finances of the missions, and report on political developments in the U.S. The second sub-section contains Humphreys' responses to the secretary of state, in which he describes his activities and those of the foreign governments with which he was dealing, and discusses events through-out Europe. Several of these letters are personal communications to Timothy Pickering; the remainder consists of file copies of some 250 official despatches written by Humphreys in his capacity as minister plenipotentiary. There is, in addition, a letterbook (Box 4, folder 110) entitled "Report of Proceedings of D. Humphreys, Relative to the secret and public transactions and Negotiations In which he was concerned from the 26th day of July 1790," which contains copies of despatches 1-54, as well as a description of Humphreys' original assignment from George Washington in 1790, his plans and preliminary activities before arriving in Europe, and copies of correspondence and secret instructions from the secretary of state.

The third sub-section of Diplomatic Correspondence consists of correspondence with persons other than the secretary of state. Arranged alphabetically, it contains for the most part letters of diplomats and government officials. Its largest component is correspondence exchanged between Humphreys and William L. Smith, minister plenipotentiary to Portugal from 1797 to 1801, in which events in Portugal are discussed. A somewhat smaller set of letters to Joel Barlow from Humphreys reports on diplomatic developments in Spain. The fourth sub-section contains electrostatic copies of all enclosures to letters in Section 1, arranged alphabetically by author; the fifth contains the two letterbooks described above. Section 2, Diplomatic Miscellany,is made up of newspaper clippings, writings, copies of petitions and other documents, and similar materials, all pertaining to Humphreys' diplomatic career. The papers are arranged chronologically.

The five remaining sections of Series I are composed of personal papers of David Humphreys. Section 3, General Correspondence,contains a small number of letters exchanged with family members, friends, and acquaintences. It is arranged alphabetically. Among the noteworthy items in this section are correspondence with David Bushnell and Ezra Lee about submarines, a letter from James Madison condemning alliance with France and trade restrictions in 1813, a letter to Humphreys' brother John describing his arrival in Lisbon, and a letter to Martha Washington on the death of her husband.

Section 4, Third-Party Correspondence,contains several items of correspondence of people other than David Humphreys, again arranged alphabetically. Of particular interest are memoranda by David Bushnell about his submarine and a letter from Benjamin Silliman describing David Humphreys' funeral.

Section 5, Literary Miscellany, is made up of drafts and notes for writings by Humphreys, and manuscript copies of letters by George Washington, all arranged chronologically, as are the contents of Section 6, Commissions, Diplomas, Certificates. The final section, Genealogy, Biography, and Engravings,is arranged by type of material.
Folders with asterisks (*) contain ten or more items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This small series contains diplomatic papers of George William Erving (1769-1850), dating for the most part from his service as charg√© d'affaires for the United States in Madrid from 1804 to 1809. No correspondence of Erving is preserved here. A memoranda book in the form of a diary records his activities in Madrid between October 1805 and February 1806, with scattered entries through July 1808. Erving describes political and diplomatic developments in Spain and gives in some detail several conversations with Spanish government officials. There are also occasional notes about social and economic conditions and about Erving's finances. Accompanying this volume is a miscellany of newspapers and other printed matter and copies of letters and documents in English, Spanish, and French, all pertaining to Spain and her American colonies, and to the progress of the Napoleonic Wars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains papers of members of the Marvin family and of the Colt and Ely families with whom they were allied by marriage (see the family chart at the beginning of the register for details). The series is divided into five sections, of which the largest by far is Family Correspondence.The letters are arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Contained here are mostly unconnected letters, although the correspondence of Elizabeth Marvin (Box 5, folders 186-187) does form a cohesive group concerning the death of her husband, Judah Colt. Bereavement and the consolations of religion are, in fact, frequent topics in this section, whose contents deal with family news and financial affairs. Only one letter diverges, that of Theophilus Marvin (Box 5, folder 193), which gives an account of a lecture about a visit to a Waldensian community in northern Italy.

The remaining papers in Series III consist of a collection of Marvin family financial papers, twelve land patents, and genealogical notes about the Marvin, Colt, and other families. Pertaining to the Ely family are financial papers of Elizabeth Colt Ely (Box 5, folder 198), and a brigade order addressed to Seth Ely (Box 5, folder 197).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV is made up of papers of Lemuel Gregory Olmsted (1808-1880), minister and natural historian. The correspondence in the series is divided into three sections, each arranged alphabetically by author: Personal Correspondence, Third-Party Correspondence, and Family Correspondence. Personal Correspondence contains Olmsted's own correspondence. Incoming letters from family and friends covers such topics as family events and genealogies and research about Joel Barlow, as well as business matters stemming from Olmsted's service as a chaplain in the Union Army. Included in the correspondence are short notes from Henry Ward Beecher, Horace Greeley, and William H. Seward, and a sequence of over sixty letters from Olmsted's daughter, Sarah Lucy, describing her life in Erie, Pennsylvania, from 1860 to 1865. Only five letters written by Olmsted are preserved here; three deal with a job at the Erie Academy. Third-Party Correspondence contains eight letters from persons other than family members. Employment and other business matters are the primary issues discussed. Family Correspondencecontains seven letters dealing with family news.

Aside from correspondence, Series IV contains a number of receipts and other miscellaneous items such as tickets, advertisements, printed matter, diplomas, and genealogical notes. Two items of particular interest are a family photograph and autograph album belonging to Sarah Lucy Olmsted and a journal kept by Lemuel Gregory Olmsted of his travels around New York State during 1830. As well as detailing his social activities and modes of travel, he describes the geological formations and flora and fauna of places he visited, and meditates on philosophical and religious questions.
Folders with asterisks (*) contain ten or more items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V is composed of five small, unrelated groups of papers dating from the Revolutionary War era through the first half of the nineteenth century. The first two sections consist of individual items: a draft of a poem by Joel Barlow, and an autobiographical narrative probably written by Christopher Cary (1763-1837). The third and largest section, Dwight Family Manuscripts,contains both family correspondence and two journals kept by Timothy Dwight (1752-1817) of travels through New England. The correspondence treats of such varied subjects as politics in Hartford, Connecticut (Box 7, folder 277), the New York City almshouse (folder 282), an unusual change in skin color of an Afro-American (folder 279), and the last wishes of Timothy Dwight given during a conversation with Theodore Dwight (1764-1846).

The fourth section of Series V contains eighteen letters to and from John Trumbull (1750-1831) and a sketch of the life of Governor Jonathan Trumbull written by John Trumbull. Included are letters to John Adams and from Aaron Burr discussing politics, and correspondence with other friends and acquaintances concerning politics, Yale College, and various scholarly matters. Since other correspondence of Trumbull is located in Series I and II of this collection, an author index to all of the Trumbull material has been appended to this register.

The final section of Series V consists of miscellaneous autograph letters and documents signed by such people as John and John Quincy Adams, Henry Clay, and George Washington. Several of the letters are copies or facsimiles; these are marked as such in the folder list which follows.
